results.title: Road sense. Part 4
results.creator_credit: Michael McCarthy, Richard F. Tambling, Ronald H. Riley and Verity Films
results.brief_description:
Made for Army Driver Training Establishments, Road Sense, made up of four short films, deals, from the driver’s seat, with some of the problems and faults encountered on the roads. The films are intended for screening during a course on driving instruction with a view to stressing the importance of care and concentration.
The fourth part deals with driving in traffic, emergency action and night driving.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Michael McCarthy, Richard F. Tambling, Ronald H. Riley and Verity Films

results.title: Road sense. Part 3
results.creator_credit: Michael McCarthy, Richard F. Tambling, Ronald H. Riley and Verity Films
results.brief_description:
Made for Army Driver Training Establishments, Road Sense, made up of four short films, deals, from the driver’s seat, with some of the problems and faults encountered on the roads. The films are intended for screening during a course on driving instruction with a view to stressing the importance of care and concentration.
The third part deals with bends; children, animals, cyclists and other unpredictable road users.

results.title: Road sense. Part 2
results.creator_credit: Michael McCarthy, Richard F. Tambling, Ronald H. Riley and Verity Films
results.brief_description:
Made for Army Driver Training Establishments, Road Sense, made up of four short films, deals, from the driver’s seat, with some of the problems and faults encountered on the roads. The films are intended for screening during a course on driving instruction with a view to stressing the importance of care and concentration.
The second deals with the importance of signals, road position of vehicles, and the hazards of overtaking.

results.title: Road sense. Part 1
results.creator_credit: Michael McCarthy, Richard F. Tambling, Ronald H. Riley and Verity Films
results.brief_description:
Made for Army Driver Training Establishments, Road Sense, made up of four short films, deals, from the driver’s seat, with some of the problems and faults encountered on the roads. The films are intended for screening during a course on driving instruction with a view to stressing the importance of care and concentration.
The first opens with a leading truck driver attributing good driving to care on the roads, and follows with some shots of typically careless driving ending with a crash. .
results.creator_credit_for_label: Michael McCarthy, Richard F. Tambling, Ronald H. Riley and Verity Films

results.title: Road manners
results.brief_description: Demonstrates the need for clear hand signals, both to keep the roads safe and as part of good driving manners. Of historic value. Filmed in Lane Cove, Sydney and features several shots of Australia’s beloved Holden.

results.title: Road lore
results.brief_description: The rules of the road are simple. If the motorist observes them they will drive well and safely. David Mackay, racing driver, explains “road lore” and how to practice it.

results.title: Rivers of sand
results.brief_description: Portrays the people called the Hamar, who live in the scrubland of Ethiopia. Points out that in this society, the men are the masters and the women are slaves and shows how this sexual inequality affects the mood and behaviour of the people. A Hamar woman speaks to the camera at intervals throughout - her words have subtitles. Suitable for secondary level.

results.title: Rivers in steel
results.creator_credit: Barry Merton and Mathias, Kenyon and Merton Pictures
results.brief_description: Shows in detail the construction of penstocks at the Murray 1 and 2 Power Stations and explains briefly the Snowy Mountains Scheme and the benefits in irrigation from the inland diversion of rivers.

results.title: Rivers at work: an introduction to channel processes
results.brief_description: Introduces some of the basic concepts of fluvial geomorphology. Shows the processes which mould the landscape, indicates how field and laboratory observations provide insight into these processes, and gives a theoretical framework through which the study of rivers can be approached.
